Effects of nanomaterials on marine invertebrates
Laura Canesi a,⁎, Ilaria Corsi b a Department of Earth, Environment and Life Sciences (DISTAV), University of Genoa, Italy b Department of Physical, Earth and Environmental Sciences (DSFTA), University of Siena, Italy
H I G H L I G H T S G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
• Marine invertebrates are significant targets for NPs released in the environment. • Most data on bivalves and echinoderms, much less in sediment dwelling species • Main biological responses: immunomodulation, oxidative stress, embryotoxicity • NP interactions with environmental/ biological components affect their fate/ toxicity. • More information on eco/bio-interactions of NPs in the marine environment is needed
⁎ Corresponding author at: DISTAV, University of Geno E-mail address: Laura.Canesi@unige.it (L. Canesi).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2016.01.085 0048-9697/© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Please cite this article as: Canesi, L., Corsi, I., E j.scitotenv.2016.01.085
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 22 November 2015 Received in revised form 14 January 2016 Accepted 14 January 2016 Available online xxxx
The development of nanotechnology will inevitably lead to the release of consistent amounts of nanomaterials (NMs) and nanoparticles (NPs) intomarine ecosystems. Ecotoxicological studies have been carried out to identify potential biological targets of NPs, and suitable models for predicting their impact on the health of themarine environment. Recent studies in invertebratesmainly focused on NP accumulation and sub-lethal effects, rather than acute toxicity. Amongmarine invertebrates, bivalves represent by large themost studied group, with polychaetes and echinoderms also emerging as significant targets of NPs. However, major scientific gaps still need to be filled. In this work, factors affecting the fate of NPs in the marine environment, and their consequent uptake/accumulation/toxicity in marine invertebrates will be summarized. The results show that in different model species, NP accumulationmainly occurs in digestive tract and gills. Data on sub-lethal effects andmodes of action of different types of NPs (mainly metal oxides and metal based NPs) in marine invertebrates will be reviewed, in particular on immune function, oxidative stress and embryo development. Moreover, the possibility that such effects may be influenced by NP interactions with biomolecules in both external and internal environment will be introduced. In natural environmental media, NP interactions with polysaccharides, proteins and colloids may affect their agglomeration/aggregation and consequent bioavailability. Moreover, once within the organism, NPs are known to interact with plasma proteins, forming a protein corona that can affect particle uptake and toxicity in target cells in a physiological environment. These interactions, leading to the formation of eco-bio-coronas, may be crucial in determining particle behavior and effects also in marine biota. In order to classify NPs into groups and predict the implications of their release into the marine environment, information on their intrinsic properties is clearly insufficient, and a deeper understanding of NP eco/bio-interactions is required.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Recent environmental fate models underline that nanowastes will end up in the aquatic environment, thus potentially affecting natural ecosystems and human health (Bystrzejewska-Piotrowska et al., 2009; Brar et al., 2010; Liu et al., 2014). Marine ecosystems, historically seen as a major sink of anthropogenic contaminants, will receive consistent amounts of nanomaterials (NMs) and nanoparticles (NPs), whose intrinsic and extrinsic complexity are making the prediction and assessment of their fate, exposure and biological effects a major challenge (Klaine et al., 2008). As recently discussed in our overview on fate models and tools (analytical and biological) for ecosafety assessment and design of NMs entering the marine environment (Corsi et al., 2014), still major scientific gaps need to be filled. The development for instance of quantitative approaches for integrating more realistic NP exposure scenarios and predicting ecosystem impacts are urgently needed for a proper risk assessment (Gottschalk et al., 2013). Ecotoxicological studies on marine organisms have so far reported a wide variety of biological injuries in species belonging to different trophic levels, from planktonic to benthic species, including fish; these studies had the general aim to identify potential biological targets aswell as suitable models for both risk assessment and prediction of marine environmental implications (Minetto et al., 2014; Baker et al., 2014; Matranga and Corsi, 2012). In order to achieve this goal, basic information on the factors affecting the behavior of NPs released in the marine environment, and consequent uptake/accumulation/toxicity by representative species must be taken into account. The importance of evaluating the potential impact of NP exposure on aquatic invertebrates has been underlined (Baun et al., 2008; Canesi et al., 2012; Baker et al., 2014; Corsi et al., 2014; Matranga and Corsi, 2012; Canesi et al., 2015; Rocha et al., 2015). The first studies were mainly carried out in freshwater species utilizing standard ecotoxicity tests, with less than 20% of published papers on marine species (Cattaneo et al., 2009). However, the number of publications on NP ecotoxicity in invertebrates has exponentially grown in the last few years, with a strong contribution of those investigating NP accumulation, sub-lethal effects and mechanisms of action, rather than on acute toxicity. Among these, the percentage of studies on marine species has risen considerably (up to 38% of the total) (Fig. 1A). Bivalve molluscs are so far the most studied marine invertebrate group (50%), whereas less attention has been focused on sediment-dwelling invertebrates (benthic infauna) (about 20%) (Fig. 1B).
Mytilus spp. represent the most utilized bivalve model: special emphasis has been given to the effects of different types of NPs on the immune system and on the main tissues involved in NP uptake and accumulation, i.e. the gills and the hepatopancreas (reviewed in Canesi et al., 2012, 2015; Rocha et al., 2015). Scattered information is available on other bivalve species andmarine invertebrate groups (echinoderms, annelids). In this work, those aspects related to the effects of NPs on
immune function, oxidative stress and early development in different invertebrate species will be analyzed in more detail. Moreover, the concept that such effectsmay be influenced byNP interactionswith biomolecules both in the external environment andwithin the body fluids, forming eco-bio-coronas, will be introduced.

sections.heading: 2. Behavior of different particles in SW
sections.text:
Environmental implications of NPs are strongly linked to their peculiar features such as particle surface charge, size, shape, functionalization and coating, all properties that affect their interaction with the surrounding media and the resulting fate and toxicity (Klaine et al., 2008). For instance, dispersion and aggregation or agglomeration in aqueous solutions are driven not only by NP size and surface charges, but also by several parameters of the receiving media, such as pH, ionic strength (osmolarity) and presence of natural organic matter (NOM) (Corsi et al., 2014; Keller et al., 2010; Petosa et al., 2010). Natural environmental scenarios are currently barely represented in nanoecotoxicological studies, this being mainly due to substantial lack of information on interactions between different NP types and exposure media such as for example natural sea water (NSW) vs artificial sea water (ASW). The high ionic strength that also affects pH, as well as organic matter content, has been reported to play a significant role on NP aggregation, thus affecting their fate in thewater columnand sediments (Chen et al., 2011). In our recent work with marine mussels Mytilus galloprovincialis, co-exposure to titanium dioxide NPs (n-TiO2) and CdCl2 in ASW resulted in reduced Cd toxicity and increased Ti accumulation in selected tissues (i.e. gills) (Della Torre et al., 2015). On the other hand, such an effect was not observed in the digestive gland, suggesting that interactions with biomolecules may affect the fate and effects of NPs within the organism. Bioavailability, as well as biodistribution and consequent biological responses, are highly dependent on exposure mechanisms, but also on the interactions of NPs inside the body of the organism itself. Further studies on NP behavior within the aquatic environment, as well as into the internal environment of exposed organisms, are therefore strongly needed.
Both heteroaggregation and homoaggregation are driven by NP surface charges and the chemical composition of the surrounding media, due to the presence of elevated concentrations of inorganic ions as well as organic molecules such as polysaccharides, proteins and colloids (Praetorius et al., 2014; Zhou et al., 2013). Moreover, the presence of functional groups on the surface of NPs, more than their core composition (metal-based, carbon-based, etc.) is now being considered to play amajor role in sorption to biofilms in high ionic strength media such as NSW. Single NPs may barely adsorb NOM, while “bridging effects” due to colloids interacting with multiple particles can increase aggregation. For instance, colloidal polymers produced by algae known as exopolymeric substances (EPS) can influence aggregation
ions on freshwater and marine invertebrates with respect to total publications on bmed); B) Number of publications on different marine invertebrate groups and genera at
and transformation of NPs in aqueous media, mainly as a function on the hydrophobic and electrostatic interactions between NPs and EPS (Nevius et al., 2012; Therezien et al., 2014; Adeleye et al., 2014a,b; Kadar et al., 2014).
Interactions of NPs with biomolecules have been described within biological fluids of mammalian models, where plasma proteins originate a coating known as protein corona, which affect cellular uptake (biokinetics) and ultimate toxicity (Lundqvist et al., 2011; Monopoli et al., 2011; Salvati et al., 2013). The formation of a NP corona has been recently reported also in terrestrial and freshwater invertebrate species, i.e. secreted proteins from the coelomic fluid of the rugworm Eisena fetida and from Daphnia magna neonates (Hayashi et al., 2013; Nasser and Lynch, 2015), and may also occur in marine invertebrates (see below).
Whether these processes could take place also in the external environment, for example in NSW as consequence of interactions with NOM, as well as within biological fluids of marine organisms, deserves further investigation. NP extrinsic properties related to the formation of an eco-corona or bio (protein) corona will affect consistently their ultimate fate in the water column and therefore biological activity and toxicity (Fig. 2). NP surface charge and size, irrespective of core composition, have been reported to play a significant role in cellular adhesion, particle recognition aswell as efficiency of uptake.We recently showed that polystyrene NP (PS NPs) having cationic (−NH2) or anionic (−COOH) surface groups undergo different aggregation in NSW, this affecting their biodistribution and ultimate toxicity both in larvae of brine shrimp Artemia franciscana, as well as sea urchin embryos Paracentrotus lividus (Della Torre et al., 2014; Bergami et al., 2015). Anionic PS NPs undergo significant aggregation in NSW and retention in the gut lumen of exposed organisms, while cationic PS NPs showed far less aggregation in NSW but clear signs of toxicity.
Several mechanisms can be involved in NP uptake, but their dispersion state in exposure media may result in the absence or presence of an eco/bio-corona, like it may occur in artificial vs natural sea water or in different body fluids (Salvati et al., 2013; Liu et al., 2011; Rossi et al., 2014). Moreover, in marine coastal areas significant changes in NOM and ion concentrations are influenced by the season and river flows, which might consistently affect NP interactions and ultimate fate and effects in both planktonic and benthic invertebrates (Corsi et al., 2014).
Please cite this article as: Canesi, L., Corsi, I., Effects of nanomaterials onma j.scitotenv.2016.01.085
In the framework of a general need to classify NPs into groups and predict environmental implications once they are released into the marine environment, information on their intrinsic properties is clearly insufficient, and a deeper understanding of eco/bio-interactions is therefore urgently needed. Moreover, ecotoxicity studies based on realistic environmental scenarios could be valuable tools for both screening and categorizing NPs for risk assessment purposes.

sections.heading: 3. Uptake and accumulation
sections.text:
NP surface charges (positive or negative), size and shape, irrespective of core composition, have been recently shown to drive cellular adhesion, particle recognition but more important uptake efficiency (Lunov et al., 2011; Varela et al., 2012). Surface charge, more than size, has an important role in cellular uptake in human cells, as for instance for polymericNPs,which are consequentlymore efficiently internalized (Bramini et al., 2014; Liu et al., 2011; Lunov et al., 2011; Rossi et al., 2014). Cationic polystyrene NPs (PS-NH2) have been shown to be cytotoxic for mammalian cells in vitro, while anionic PS NPs (PSCOOH) exhibited greater and rapid accumulation in selected organs such as lung (Bexiga et al., 2011; Wang et al., 2013a, 2013b). Recent findings on sea urchin embryos and brine shrimp larvae confirmed such behavior; significant gut retention is observed for anionic PS-COOH NPs while cationic PS-NH2 NPs showed respectively developmental toxicity and increase of molts (Della Torre et al., 2014; Bergami et al., 2015). Studies in other marine invertebrate species confirm a significant accumulation of anionic PS NPs in the gut of rotifers (Snell and Hicks, 2011) and in bivalves (Ward and Kach, 2009; Wegner et al., 2012). Nanoscale aggregates of PS-NH2 (~100 nm) are still present in NSW media while PS-COOH NPs originated microscale aggregates (N900 nm) (Della Torre et al., 2014; Bergami et al., 2015). The formation of NP aggregates in dispersing media has a strong influence on their route of uptake and biodistribution. Bioaccumulation seems in general not affecting mortality in short-term exposure scenarios, but it has been associated with several sub-lethal effects (mainly behavioral and physiological i.e. increased molting frequency) that might affect species survival in long-term exposure scenarios (Bergami et al., 2015; manuscript in preparation). Accumulation of NP aggregates in the digestive tract, as observed for PS-COOH NPs, can significantly limit food intake and disrupt growth and development of planktonic invertebrate larvae (Bergami et al., 2015; Besseling et al., 2014). In addition, adsorption of hydrophobic aquatic pollutants by nano-debris may increase their bioavailability and consequent cellular uptake once accumulated in the gut (Rochman et al., 2013; Velzeboer et al., 2014). As for inorganic NPs, a general mechanism of uptake of aggregates by endocytosis in the digestive system and individual NPs or ionic forms in the gills, respectively, has been hypothesized; however, a higher accumulation of nano- compared to micro-metric sized particles has been reported for soluble metals as gold and copper (both ions and NPs) (Canesi et al., 2010; Gomes et al., 2011, 2012; Dai et al., 2013). The ability of NPs to act as carriers of toxic contaminants seems to be affected by their dispersion in exposure media and also to be linked to the absence or presence of NP-eco/biomolecular coronas (Monopoli et al., 2011; Lesniak et al., 2013; Salvati et al., 2013). Moreover, how both type and fate of the corona (hard and soft corona) will affect uptake and bioaccumulation, as reported in mammalian systems, still represents a major challenge and deserve further investigation in both adults and larval/ embryo stages of marine invertebrate species.
In bivalves mucus, fecal pellets and gametes can have a significant role in bioavailability of NPs but also on their uptake by different organs (i.e. gills or digestive gland) (Della Torre et al., 2015; Rocha et al., 2015). At the level of the cell membrane, ATP-binding cassette transporters belonging to the ABC family have been shown to have a significant a role in NP biodistribution. As recently reported in Caco-2 gut epithelial cells, n-TiO2 (anatase) significantly increases the functionality of the cells, then forms a protective barrier against exogenous toxicants and
rine invertebrates, Sci Total Environ (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/
on nutrient absorption (Dorier et al., 2015). Our recent studies on mussels exposed to n-TiO2 showed similar resultswith a significant increase in efflux of Rhodamine B (RhB), a P-glycoprotein substrate, from the gills, suggesting that this protective role could be also shared by selected barrier organs as the gills of marine invertebrates (Canesi et al., 2014; Della Torre et al., 2015). Further studies are thus needed in order to clarify the role of efflux activity of ABC transporters in marine invertebrates upon exposure to selected NPs and therefore on their toxicity.

sections.heading: 4. Effects and mode of action of NPs in marine invertebrate models
4.1. Effects on immune function
sections.text:
Increasing evidence supports the hypothesis that in marine invertebrates the immune system represents a significant target for the effects of NPs. Invertebrates lack an adaptive immunity: however, they are endowed with a potent and complex innate immune system (humoral and cellular defenses) similar to that of vertebrates. In most invertebrates, free circulating cells (hemocytes/coelomocytes) are responsible for cell-mediated immunity; when activated, different hemocyte types are capable of phagocytosis, reactive oxygen species (ROS) and NO production, release of hydrolytic enzymes and antimicrobial peptides. Conservation of the general mechanisms of innate immunity from invertebrates to mammals is a key feature that represents a useful basis for evaluating the environmental impact of NPs (Canesi and Prochàzovà, 2013).
In M. galloprovincialis, in vitro studies showed that different NP types (carbon black, fullerenes, and different nanosized metal-oxides) are rapidly taken up byhemocytes, affecting different functional parameters, from lysosomal function to phagocytic activity and oxyradical production, and also inducing pro-apoptotic processes. The effects were mediated by stress-activated mitogen activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling, as in mammalian phagocytes, and were observed in the concentration range of 1–10 μg/mL (Canesi et al., 2012; Canesi and Prochàzovà, 2013). Recent studies also showed that amino-modified PS NPs (PS-NH2) induced significant activation of immune parameters at lower concentrations (1–5 μg/mL), whereas lysosomal damage and apoptotic process were observed at higher concentrations (50 μg/mL) (Canesi et al., 2015). Different NPs were shown to target the phagocytic activity also in the hemocytes of the oyster Crassostrea gigas (Abbott Chalew et al., 2012) and of the clam Ruditapes decussatus (Marisa et al., 2015). Interestingly, induction of functional responses, as well as of cellular damage and apoptotic processes, was particularly rapid, occurring within 1 h of exposure. This is in line with the physiological role of bivalve hemocytes, which represent the first line of defense against non-self material (Canesi and Prochàzovà, 2013).
Another in vitro approach has been successfully utilized to evaluate NP-mediated cytoxicity inMytilus hemocytes after prolonged exposure (24 h) to different types of NPs (CdS quantum dots, nanosized Au and Ag NPs, n-ZnO, n-SiO2, n-TiO2) in a wide concentration range; the effects were compared with those observed in isolated gill cells (Katsumiti et al., 2014, 2015a, 2015b, 2015c). These studies underlined different cytotoxic effects in terms of cell viability (EC50), and parameters related to oxidative stress, genotoxicity, cytoskeletal alterations, and membrane transport activities. Moreover, various degrees of toxicities were observed in hemocytes and gill cells that were related to the NP mode of synthesis, crystalline structure and size, presence of additives in the suspensions, metal ion release in high ionic strength medium, etc.
Overall, the application of a battery of functional/toxicity tests on bivalve hemocytes proved as a powerful tool for the screening of the immunomodulatory/immunotoxic effects of different types of NPs in cell models of marine organisms, as well as a robust alternative method for testing the toxicity of NPs and a possible basis for a ‘safety by design’ approach (reviewed in Canesi et al., 2012; Canesi and Prochàzovà, 2013).
Please cite this article as: Canesi, L., Corsi, I., Effects of nanomaterials onma j.scitotenv.2016.01.085
The results obtained in vitroonmussel immune cellswere confirmed by in vivo exposure to different NPs, and in particular to n-TiO2 chosen as a model NP type (Canesi et al., 2010; Barmo et al., 2013). These data allowed formulating a hypothesis on the possible pathways leading to nano-induced immunomodulation (Canesi and Prochàzovà, 2013; Corsi et al., 2014). Due to the physiological mechanisms involved in the feeding process, n-TiO2 agglomerates/aggregates formed in sea water are taken up by the gills and partly directed to the digestive gland. NPs can be then potentially translocated from the digestive system to the hemolymph, and to circulating hemocytes, where n-TiO2 induces changes in functional parameters, as well as in transcription of different antimicrobial peptides and downregulation of Toll-like receptors (Barmo et al., 2013; Balbi et al., 2014). Interestingly, these effects were observed at concentrations much lower than those usually utilized in ecotoxicity tests on aquatic species (1–100 μg/L), and closer to predicted environmental concentrations (PEC) (Gottschalk et al., 2013).
Sea urchin immune cells represent another suitable model for testing the effects of NPs on the immune system of marine invertebrates. Well established as sensors of environmental hazards, coelomocytes of the Mediterranean species P. lividus have been recently shown to activate/express specific cell stress proteins upon n-TiO2 exposure both in in vitro and ex vivo (Pinsino and Matranga, 2015; Pinsino et al., 2015). Moreover, in vivo exposure elicited a phagocytic mechanism, involving the TLR/p38MAPK signaling pathway (Pinsino et al., 2015). This species has been used to study the in vivo potential toxicity of a few selected metal oxide NPs (i. e. SnO2, CeO2, Fe3O4), introduced by forced ingestion (Falugi et al., 2012). After 5 days, nano-aggregates/agglomerates were found inside the sea urchin immune cells (coelomocytes), causingmodifications of the trans-Golgi and ER subcellular compartments, inhibiting the activity of the three Cholinesterase (ChE) isoforms and affecting the expression levels of the stress proteins HSC70 and GRP78 (Falugi et al., 2012). In contrast to what was expected by analogy with bivalve molluscs, injection of n-TiO2 into the coelomic cavity did not cause a stress response in the sea urchin, nor immune cell death or autophagy and lysosomal dysfunction (Pinsino et al., 2015).
Phenoloxidase PO and lysozyme activities were induced by AgNP aggregates in the clam Scrobicularia plana and in the polychaete Nereis (Hediste) diversicolor, respectively (Mouneyrac et al., 2014). In the coelomocytes of H. diversicolor, AgNPs induced lysosomal and DNA damage (Cong et al., 2014). These results indicate that NPs may affect the function of immune cells also in marine worms.
The availability of the sea urchin genome, shown to be in close phylogenetic relationship to the humans (Sodergren et al., 2006), offers the possibility to analyze its complex and sophisticated immune systemand compare the biological effects observed in sea urchins and human phagocytes. Although theMytilus genome is not available yet, the rapidly expanding application of DNA microarrays and Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) is leading to the identification of an increasing number of immune-related genes that could represent the target for different NPs also in mussels (Philipp et al., 2012; Gerdol and Venier, 2015). In this light, both the mussel and the sea urchin represent promising models for evaluating the effects of NPs on the immune system of marine invertebrates.

sections.heading: 4.2. Effects of NPs at tissue level
sections.text:
Oxidative stress and cell injury in proteins, membrane and DNA damage have been so far identified as the major modes of action of NPs in bivalve tissues (reviewed in Rocha et al., 2015). However, the paradigm proposed to explain most of the adverse effects exerted by NP exposure in mussels, that is, all the effects that are directly or indirectly mediated by reactive oxygen species (ROS) and free radical production, cannot be applied to all NP types. Moreover, oxidative damage induced by NPs in bivalves depends on particle size, composition
rine invertebrates, Sci Total Environ (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/
and concentration, mode and time of exposure, as well as the target organ analyzed.
In Mytilus gills, short-term exposure (24 h) to both carbon based NPs (nano carbon black-nNCB, C60 fullerene), and n-oxides (n-TiO2 and n-SiO2) (0.05, 0.2, 1, 5 mg/L) induced changes in catalase and GST activities, with both increases and decreases depending on NP type and concentration; however, antioxidant enzymes did not seem to represent a significant target for these types of NPs (Canesi et al., 2010). Longer exposure to n-TiO2 (0.1 mg/L, 96 h) increased P-gp efflux activity and NO production; this latter effect may be mainly due to infiltrating hemocytes, since no changes in antioxidant enzyme activities were observed (Della Torre et al., 2014). Although the gills of C. gigas and M. galloprovincialis are susceptible to oxidative stress induced by ZnO and CuO NPs, this was not the case with other metalbased NPs (reviewed in Rocha et al., 2015). Gene transcription profiles were not significantly altered in the gills ofM. galloprovincialis exposed to Ag NPs after 15 days, although changes in expression may occur at shorter times of exposure (Bebianno et al., 2015).
As described above, NP behavior (aggregation/agglomeration) in both ASW and NSW is a key factor in their accumulation and effects in different tissues. Although mussel gills are the first organ/barrier to surrounding water, being more vulnerable to particle interactions, uptake of individual NPs or ionic metal forms seems to mainly occur in this tissue, while NP agglomerates may enter in the digestive system of the organism mainly by endocytosis (Corsi et al., 2014; Rocha et al., 2015).
In bivalves, the digestive gland is therefore considered the main organ for accumulation of NPs, where their cellular fate and effect differ according to the NP type and experimental conditions. The endosomal– lysosomal system of digestive cells, due to its role in intracellular digestion of food particles, represents the main subcellular target for NPs in bivalves (Moore, 2006; Canesi et al., 2012). In Mytilus digestive gland, acute exposure (24 h) to NP suspensions (NCB, C60, n-TiO2, nSiO2) induced lysosomal membrane destabilization, decreases in antioxidant defenses and lipofuscin accumulation, indicating oxidative stress conditions only at high concentrations (N1 mg/L) (Canesi et al., 2010). At lower concentrations (1–100 μg/L) and longer times of exposure (96 h), tissue antioxidant defenses were apparently able to cope with potential oxidative stress conditions induced by n-TiO2 (Barmo et al., 2013). Inwhole tissues of the endobenthic bivalve S. plana, the response of oxidative stress biomarkers was more important after dietary thanwaterborne exposure to AgNPs; however, defenses were relatively efficient since no biomarkers of damage were observed. Moreover, labile Ag released from AgNPs was mainly responsible for the observed effects (Buffet et al., 2013). Mesocosm exposure to low concentrations of n-CuO resulted in induction of oxidative stress biomarkers but not in lipid peroxidation in both S. plana and H. diversicolor (Buffet et al., 2014). In Ruditapes philippinarum digestive gland, exposure to predicted environmental concentrations (0.75 μg/L) of AuNPs induced oxidative stress and inflammatory response markers, as measured by phase II antioxidant enzymes and q-PCR gene expression analysis; however, the overall magnitude of responses was low, and oxidative damage was not observed (Volland et al., 2015).
Application of proteomics in mussel tissues revealed oxidative changes in response to different metal-based NPs (reviewed in Rocha et al., 2015). In particular, tissue redox proteomics indicated that NP size is a key factor in determining biological responses in mussels exposed to AuNPs (Tedesco et al., 2010).
Overall, the results suggest that, although the mechanisms of action of NPs in marine invertebrates can be ascribed to increased radical production/changes in antioxidant defenses, exposure to different types of NPs, at concentrations compatible with predicted environmental levels, does not seem to elicit significant oxidative stress at the tissue level. Oxidative stress conditions observed with mostly metal-based NPs (namely containing Ag, Cu, Zn, Au, Fe) could be mainly related to dissolution of free metal ions from the particles (Baker et al., 2008).

sections.heading: 4.3. Effects on development
sections.text:
The application of early life stage toxicity tests, involving exposure during the most sensitive stages of the organism to environmental stress, would greatly help in the identification of those chemicals that represent a major threat to marine species. This also applies to studies on the biological impact of NPs onmarine invertebrateswhere, complementary to the use of adult specimens, embryos have emerged as valid tools for studies on developmental perturbations induced by different types of NMs (metal based NPs and metal-oxides, carbon based NPs, nanopolymers, etc.).
Echinoderms have been so far the most studied taxonomic group of marine invertebrates used for assessing NP developmental toxicity. In the white sea urchin Lytechinus pictus no toxicity of n-TiO2 and n-SiO2 was observed. In contrast, n-ZnO was highly toxic (EC50 = 99.5 μg/L). However, toxicity of n-ZnO was similar to that of soluble Zn2+, and was shown to be related to particle dissolution in sea water (Fairbairn et al., 2011). In P. lividus, exposure to AgNPs caused dose-dependent developmental defects as well as alterations in swimming patterns: however, the cause–effect relationship was not demonstrated (Siller et al., 2013). In Strongylocentrotus droebachiensis, Ag+, AgNPs and f-SWCNTs, separately and in mixtures, induced different developmental defects in exposed embryos (Magesky and Pelletier, 2015).
Burić et al. (2015) showed that the effects of AgNPs on embryonal development in Mediterranean sea urchin species (Arbacia lixula, P. lividus and Sphaerechinus granularis) were species-specific. The most sensitive species was A. lixula, with high numbers of malformed embryos or arrested development observed at the lowest AgNP concentrations tested (1–10 μg/L). Moreover, the greatest impact on development was noted for those embryos first exposed to NPs at 6 and 24 h post fertilization, thus underlying how the timing of exposure to NPs may represent an important factor in the development of abnormalities.
In P. lividus, n-SiO2 did not affect fertilization, whereas undeveloped and anomalous embryos were observed at the gastrula stage (EC50 = 0.06 mg/L), and at the pluteus stage, including skeletal anomalies and delayed larvae (EC50 = 0.27 mg/L) (Gambardella et al., 2015).
The first data on bivalve molluscs showed that in the oyster Crassostrea virginica C60 fullerene affected embryonic development and lysosomal membrane stability from concentrations as low as 10 μg/L (Ringwood et al., 2009). AgNP also induced lysosomal membrane destabilization and up-regulation of metallothionein (MT) gene expression; however, it was not established whether these effects were due to the NPs themselves or to Ag2+ dissociation (Ringwood et al., 2010).
In M. galloprovincialis, n-TiO2 did not affect embryo development unless at high mg/L concentrations (Libralato et al., 2013, Balbi et al., 2014). Similarly, embryos were unaffected by Fe2O3 NPs (Kadar et al., 2010). On the other hand, sperm preincubation with stabilized (i.e., coated with organic polyacrylic stabilizer) and nonstabilized forms of zero-valent nanoiron (nZVI) caused serious disruption of development (30%mortality among spermatozoa, 20% decline in fertilization success, and delay in development) (Kadar et al., 2011). The effects of sperm pre-incubation with coated zero-valent iron (nZVI) were compared on early life stage development of three key marine invertebrate species: M. galloprovincialis, Ciona intestinalis and Psammechinus milliaris. Disruption of embryo developmentwasmost severe in sea squirts followed by mussels, while the urchin embryos were not significantly affected. Decreases in fertilization success and delay in embryo development were observed, and the effect was more severe with the coated form, possibly owing to its better colloidal stability (Kadar et al., 2013). The effects of two coated AgNPs (oleic acid coated AgNPs and polyvinylpyrrolidone coated AgNPs) on marine benthic invertebrate larvae across three phyla (i.e., the barnacle Balanus amphitrite, the slipper-limpet Crepidula onyx, and the polychaete Hydroides elegans) were evaluated in terms of growth, development, and metamorphosis (Chan and Chiu, 2015). Chronic exposure to coated AgNPs resulted in a significant
rine invertebrates, Sci Total Environ (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/
delay in growth and development and reduction of larval settlement rate, in a species-specific manner. Types of surface coatings did not affect the sub-lethal toxicity of AgNPs. However, uptake of coated AgNPs were observed in the vacuoles of epithelial cell in the digestive tract of C. onyx, suggesting that coated AgNPs could be taken up through diet and the toxicity of coated AgNPs might be mediated through toxic Ag+, as well as the novel modalities of coated AgNPs.
In the deposit feeder annelid Platynereis dumerilii, exposure to various concentrations of citrate (cit-Ag NPs) or humic acid (HA-Ag NPs) capped silver NPs (Ag NPs) induced abnormal development rates, which were higher in younger life stages. Both Ag NPs were more toxic than AgNO3 (García-Alonso et al., 2014).
Overall, the results obtained in different species and experimental conditions with metal based NPs indicate that, although the observed effects can be largely due tometal ion solubilization in sea water, developmental toxicity may be also due to other mechanisms that are particle-specific. Moreover, particle coating may contribute to toxicity, possibly owing to its better colloidal stability or differences in uptake routes in different types of embryos.
Although these studies demonstrated that, in marine invertebrates, embryo development can represent a significant target for different types of NPs, in a concentration range of μg/L–low mg/L, information on the mechanisms underlying the observed developmental effects is still extremely scarce. In P. lividus SiO2 NPs caused neurotoxic damage and a decrease in Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) expression in a nondose-dependent manner (Gambardella et al., 2015). In the same species, aminomodified polystyrene NPs (PS-NH2) caused severe developmental defects at both 24 and 48 h pf, whereas carboxylated particles (PS-COOH) were ineffective. Distinct effects were observed on transcription of selected genes; the Abcb1 transporter was up-regulated at 48 h pf by PS-COOHwhereas PS-NH2 induced cas8 gene at 24 h pf, suggesting an apoptotic pathway (Della Torre et al., 2014). In the larvae of the brine shrimp Artemia salina, exposure to SnO2, CeO2 and Fe3O4 NPs (from 0.01 to 1.0 mg/mL) induced changes in swimming speed and alterations and cholinesterase, glutathione-S-transferase and catalase activities, with different effects depending on the NP type (Gambardella et al., 2015). Further studies are needed in order to identify the molecular and cellular targets involved in the sensitivity of marine invertebrate embryos and larvae to NP exposure.

sections.heading: 4.4. NP interactions with biological fluids: the protein corona
sections.text:
As described above, NPs undergo considerable environmental transformations before reaching the target biological system: however, the evaluation of the biological effects of NPs requires additional understanding of how, once within the organism, NPs interact at the molecular level with cells in a physiological environment.
In mammalian systems, extracellular serum proteins adsorb onto the NP surface, forming a protein corona which affects particle interactions with target cells (Lundqvist et al., 2008; Fleischer and Payne, 2014 and refs. quoted therein). The corona proteins control the specific cellular receptors used by protein–NP complex, the cellular internalization pathways, and the immune response. Cells recognize the biomolecular corona around a NP, but the biological identity of the complex may be considerably different among mammalian species.
In this light, there is the intriguing possibility that NPs may interact with extracellular medium or plasma proteins in lower organisms such as marine invertebrates. The formation of a NP protein corona has been described so far only in two invertebrate species. In the earthworm E. fetida, soluble coelomic proteins (EfCP) secreted by coelomocytes, form a long-lived corona around AgNPs (Hayashi et al., 2013). Incubation of AgNPs with coelomic proteins leads to formation over time of AgNP-EfCP corona complexes that induce significantly greater NP accumulation in coelomocytes. The effects are species specific and NPspecific. In D. magna neonates, proteins secreted in the growing medium formed a coating around PS NPs; such an eco-bio-corona leads to
Please cite this article as: Canesi, L., Corsi, I., Effects of nanomaterials onma j.scitotenv.2016.01.085
particle agglomeration and increase in uptake and toxicity (Nasser and Lynch, 2015).
Data on formation of a NP-protein corona in marine invertebrates are still lacking: however, in Mytilus hemocytes exposed to PS-NH2 in the presence of hemolymph serum, an increase in lysosomalmembrane damage was observed in comparison with only sea water as incubation medium (Canesi et al., 2015). Such an effect seems driven by specific type of NP, since it was not observed for instance in n-TiO2 -exposed hemocytes (Canesi, data not shown), suggesting that a NP-protein corona might also be formed in biological fluids of marine invertebrates that may affect NP–cell interactions.
In general, the presence of proteins reduces NP surface energy by nonspecific adsorption, leading to loweredmembrane adhesion and uptake efficiency (Lesniak et al., 2013). Therefore, formation of the protein corona in mammalian serum is considered as a general protective effect from the potential cytotoxicity of NPs. In contrast, in earthworms, it was hypothesized that long-lived proteins present on the NPs (hard corona) function as recognizable molecular patterns for coelomocytes, making the NP-protein complexes “visible” for clearance by these phagocytic cells responsible for innate immunity (Hayashi et al., 2013). Moreover, the results obtained in D. magna, a filter feeder that can selectively take up food particles based on size, texture and consistency, suggested that the larger size of NPs caused by the destabilization of the proteins in the eco-corona could make the NPs a more attractive size food source and therefore cause D. magna to take up protein-coated NPs more readily than bare and monodisperse NPs (Nasser and Lynch, 2015). The results obtained in the hemocytes of marine mussels in the presence of hemolymph serum, although preliminary, seem to support this hypothesis. In this light, research is in progress on NP-corona proteins in mussels as suitable model marine invertebrates.
Overall, these data point out the determinant role of the recognizable biological identity during in vitro testing of NPs with invertebrate immune cells; however, the results obtained so far suggest that in invertebrate species the formation of a protein corona may increase the potential for NP toxicity, rather than play a protective role as in mammalian systemsHowever, the protein composition of extracellularfluids of marine invertebrates is largely unknown, given the large diversity of phyla and species, and different proteins may be involved in the formation of a stable corona around different NPs in different invertebrate groups. In earthworms, lysenin was identified as the major corona protein for AgNP (Hayashi et al., 2013), and different secreted proteins related to cell-to-cell signaling were identified in D. magna (Nasser and Lynch, 2015). InMytilus, soluble hemolymphproteins have been recently characterized by proteomics (Oliveri et al., 2014). Among these the major serum protein, Extrapallial Protein (EP) plays a crucial role in non-self recognition (Pezzati et al., 2015) and represents a possible candidate for NP corona formation.
Overall, the results obtained so far underline the need for understanding how the formation of a NP protein corona may affect the biological outcome of NP exposure in invertebrates in comparison to mammalian systems.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and perspectives
sections.text:
Different invertebrate species are now being recognized as significant biological targets for NPs. Available data show that laboratory exposure to different types of NPs, in a wide concentration range, elicits significant biological responses, from immunomodulation and oxidative stress to developmental defects. However, since the majority of studies have been so far obtained in species living in the water column, more information is needed in those species living in close contact with sediments, where NP settlement/deposition, and consequent concentrations, may be higher.
While recognizing the importance of the studies carried out so far, it is becoming clear that information on the physico-chemical properties of pristine NPs, or on their behavior in low ionic strength aqueous
rine invertebrates, Sci Total Environ (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/
solutions, is insufficient to predict their behavior in sea water and consequent uptake/accumulation/effects inmarine organisms. Future studies should address NP fate in complex environmental matrices, such as SW and sediments, as well as their interactions with biomolecules present in both environmental media and biological fluids. These ecobio–interactions may play a crucial role in particle uptake and accumulation, as well as in their distribution, fate and effects within the organism. In the absence of experimental data on occurrence and concentrations of NPs in the marine environment, especially in coastal areas that represent themajor sites of potential discharge, this information may be crucial in understanding whether the biological responses of marine invertebrates to NP exposure observed in laboratory experimentsmay be utilized for risk assessment and prediction of their impact on the health of the marine environment.

Recent environmental fate models underline that nanowastes will end up in the aquatic environment, thus potentially affecting natural ecosystems and human health (Bystrzejewska-Piotrowska et al., 2009; Brar et al., 2010; Liu et al., 2014).

Marine ecosystems, historically seen as a major sink of anthropogenic contaminants, will receive consistent amounts of nanomaterials (NMs) and nanoparticles (NPs), whose intrinsic and extrinsic complexity are making the prediction and assessment of their fate, exposure and biological effects a major challenge (Klaine et al., 2008).

As recently discussed in our overview on fate models and tools (analytical and biological) for ecosafety assessment and design of NMs entering the marine environment (Corsi et al., 2014), still major scientific gaps need to be filled.

The development for instance of quantitative approaches for integrating more realistic NP exposure scenarios and predicting ecosystem impacts are urgently needed for a proper risk assessment (Gottschalk et al., 2013).

Environmental implications of NPs are strongly linked to their peculiar features such as particle surface charge, size, shape, functionalization and coating, all properties that affect their interaction with the surrounding media and the resulting fate and toxicity (Klaine et al., 2008).

For instance, dispersion and aggregation or agglomeration in aqueous solutions are driven not only by NP size and surface charges, but also by several parameters of the receiving media, such as pH, ionic strength (osmolarity) and presence of natural organic matter (NOM) (Corsi et al., 2014; Keller et al., 2010; Petosa et al., 2010).

This is in line with the physiological role of bivalve hemocytes, which represent the first line of defense against non-self material (Canesi and Prochàzovà, 2013).

Overall, the application of a battery of functional/toxicity tests on bivalve hemocytes proved as a powerful tool for the screening of the immunomodulatory/immunotoxic effects of different types of NPs in cell models of marine organisms, as well as a robust alternative method for testing the toxicity of NPs and a possible basis for a ‘safety by design’ approach (reviewed in Canesi et al., 2012; Canesi and Prochàzovà, 2013).

metadata.abstractText: • Marine invertebrates are significant targets for NPs released in the environment. • Most data on bivalves and echinoderms, much less in sediment dwelling species • Main biological responses: immunomodulation, oxidative stress, embryotoxicity • NP interactions with environmental/ biological components affect their fate/
